THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

DECEMBER 19, 1902.

No. 5.

THE BLACK SATCHEL.
CCJ M MODATION for Cleveland, Chicago, and the Northwest!"
bawled the porter, walking through the main waiting-room of the
depot. The few travelers who sat drowsily around roused themselves, and passed out of the warm station and through the grated doors into
the snow and cold of a winter night. I had just time to purchase my ticket,
and tightly clutching my small black satchel to step on the platform, when the
midnight train, its dazzling head-light cutting through the darkness, rolled into
the depot—ten minutes late.
Crossing several tracks, I walked quickly down the long line of baggage,
express, and passenger cars, and boarded the last coach. The steam rushed
and hissed angrily from the dome of the engine as if the mighty creature were
impatient at the delay, and wished to be off and once more rush through the
darkening clouds of snow, and awaken the sleeping hills and hollows with its
hoarse shriek. The huge engine quivered and shook, snorted once, twice, and
then again and again, moved slowly forward, and in a moment was well under
way, and tearing through the night with a thousand miles of track before it.
I settled myself back in my seat, and prepared to pass the long night ride
as comfortably as I could. The smell of smoke reached me, the door was
slammed, and the brakeman, carrying a lantern in each hand, passed through
the car, leaving me its sole occupant. Solitude, it is said, is most conducive
to thought, and in a short time the events of the day were passing through my
mind in rapid review, and in particular, those which had culminated in my
leaving New York at midnight for the West. I glanced at the small black
satchel which lay on the seat beside me, and instinctively felt for my arms.
My thought flew back to the first day, not many years ago—for I was still a
young man—that I had entered the service of Thomson & Blank, bankers, one
of the largest firms in Wall Street. By degrees I had worked my way up,
gradually gaining the esteem and good-will of the firm, till now I occupied the
chief place in their large establishment. Frequently before I had been sent on
errands similar to the one in which I was at present engaged, but none was
ever of such vast importance. Frequently large sums of money had been entrusted to my care, but never before such an amount as the small black satchel
now contained. It was in the afternoon of the first day of February, 1871, that
I had been called into the small private office of Mr. Thomson. It was an
hour later that I emerged, having received full instructions regarding my mission,—the details of which for certain reasons I will not make known,—but let
it suffice that I was to act as the firm's confidential agent in consummating one
of the largest deals in which it had ever been engaged.. The entire affair so far
44

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

as known to the firm and myself, had been kept a jealously guarded secret; but
to make certain that they could not be forestalled in the transaction, and for the
quicker transfer of such a sum, it was decided that I should leave that very
night.
With a start I came out of my reverie. I had almost dozed off. A little
frightened, and now throughly awake, I lit a cigar, and turning to the window
tried to gaze into the blackness beyond. We dashed through some small town,
scarcely distinguishable in the darkness and the storm, and in a moment left it
behind us. Straining my eyes in the effort to pierce the night, I saw the red
sparks streaming by, and occasionally caught the dim outline of a house or
tree We passed through a cut, the light from the car racing and dancing over
its snow-covered side, and framing in pale streaks the bushes and shrubbery that
raced by. Once more we emerged upon the open plain, rolling away to the
westward and lost in the black blur of the distant foothills. The train rumbled
over a trestle, the narrow rapid stream flowing far below. A chill passed over
me when I thought of the possibility of jumping the rail. I turned back to
the brightly lighted car, and gave a slight start. So absorbed had I been in
trying to pierce the darkness, that I had not heard two men enter, who now
occupied seats in front of me and on opposite Sides of the aisle. Evidently,
they were strangers, and each seemed absorbed with his own thoughts. I fell
to studying the man on my left; he was well built and of genteel appearance,
dressed quietly and with taste, his hair was jet black, and he was, at least as
far as I could judge from the profile turned toward me, of a dark complexion.
The second traveler was of the ordinary type, large, robust, and light-haired.
My cigar had gone out; I lit it again, and the dark man turned partly around
in his seat, then arose, and, approaching me with an easy grace, asked for a
match. I accommodated him, and he bowed slightly. "Going to Chicago?"
he said.
"Yes. Will you sit down?" And I made room for him on the seat beside
me. In a short time we were launched deeply in conversation. Time passed
and the train rushed on, the cars swinging and jarring as we rounded some
curve. My companion I soon found to be an educated and well-read man.
Presently, however, the conversation began to lag, and laying his cigar down
on the arm of his seat, the stranger seemed lost in thought. I glanced at the
other occupant of the coach. He was to all appearances asleep.
Somehow I was seized by a terrible presentiment of impending danger, one
of those inexplicable sensations which sometimes come to a man in battle or in
times of great excitement. I turned to my companion, and uttered a cry. He
had risen from his seat, and standing in the aisle, with an indescrible look upon
his dark face, was pointing toward the rear of the car. He wheeled about like
a flash. There was a crashing blow on my head, lights innumerable danced
before my eyes, my brain was on fire. I seemed to be sinking, sinking, for
countless ages always down, down, and at last was smothered and swallowed
up in darkness, and then drowsiness came over me. I had no desire to see or to
hear, only a great longing to forget. It seemed as if the current of my mind
had stopped.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
On opening my eyes I became conscious of a burning pain in my head.
My first thought was of the black satchel. I felt beside me. It was gone!
I was bewildered, semi conscious, and possessed by an awful feeling of
unreality. My surroundings were not familiar, but by degrees as my mind
gradually cleared, I became aware that I was lying on a hard, polished floor
beside a couch. I put my hand to my head; it was covered with blood. There
was blood also upon the floor. I must have had a severe fall.
The room was spacious and magnificently furnished. Strange! I did not
know where I was. Then I thought of the satchel and my mission and grew
sick at the thought. I heard a light foot step, and a lady entered the room.
She was of middle age and still handsome.
"We dine at six, John," she said softly.
Turning to her I replied bluntly, "Where am I?"
"J—J—Why, really, what is the matter," stammered the lady. "Are you
feeling—er—as well as usual, John?"
"In heaven's name—," I began, "where am I, and who are you?"
"I am your wife and you are in your own home in London. Don't you
know—"
"How do I know?" I cried wildly. ti 9,
"You have gone mad,'' she said.
Turning I saw a large mirror at one end of the room. I quickly approached
it, but fell back aghast. In place of my own,features the mirror reflected theface
of an old man—a man prematurely aged,—with white locks and a long snowy beard!
I looked at myself with horror-stricken eyes and jaw half fallen. Then every
object danced around me, the room and the lady became lost in a giddy maze,
and my senses failed
When I regained consciousness, I found myself in bed, with kind though
unfamiliar faces around me. A violent fever kept me for weeks within the
shadow -of death, but thanks to the tender care of the lady who had claimed to
be my wife, I slowly recovered. During my convalescence I was told the story
of my second life. It was for the most part ordinary enough. I had turned
up in London one day, a poor but perfectly rational man, but without the
slightest remembrances of my life previous to the night adventure in the railway car. I had engaged in business, met with success, and married, and
would have died without ever having found out my real name, had not my fall
from a sofa upon the hard floor and the consequent injury to my head restored
my reason in a manner most miraculous. All this and much besides my wife
told me as I recovered slowly from my long illness.
The story of my early life was nearly as much of a relevation to my wife as
her story was to me. I was now once more a healthy and happy man. And
there remains but little more to tell. My first duty was to communicate with
my old employers, Thomson & Blank. The result of my inquiry was to find
out that the partnership had been long since dissolved and that both the old
gentlemen were dead. They, as I myself, would never learn the fate of the
black satchel.
E. P. SANPRocK, '03.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
THE LOOM OF DREAMS.
What shall I weave upon my loom of dreams
To give my lady in a dainty rhyme?
Some sylvan memory of summer time,
Of silent woods and slow and sleepy streams?
Some fantasy of fairy-like design,
With opal woof and warp of amethyst,
Like little waves by melting moon-beams kissed
When it cloth seem the stars forget to shine?
Or shall it be a song in martial strain,
Or a wild song of the wild, winter sea?
A dirge for A atunin, a low threnody,
As if the wind did to the moon complain?
No, none of these; for her my dream-loom weaves
Dream-fancies of a land forever Spring;
Where fountains 'neath the wooing willows sing
Of youth and love, echoed by rustling leaves.
Such was the scene those Springs in Arcady
When still the gods inhabited the vales,
And l'an went piping through the grassy dales
With dancing nymphs to keep him company.
Just such a fancy shall my dream-loom weave,
All built of airy nothings which are gone
On waking, like the yellow stars at dawn;
And yet the mind some impress doth receive,
Some impress faint, as of a long-lost song
Heard once in childhood from a crooning nurse.
I'll charm my lady's ear with such a verse
As might be sung at eve by elfin throng.
'Tis this I'll weave out of the idle air
To cast around her in a mystic spell;
0 may she own she could not think to dwell
E'en in that dream unles4 I could be there!

. SPLENDID talk was delivered during the meeting at the Medical School
Sunday evening. Mr. Mott spoke very powerfully of the Christian work
in universities and colleges of North America, Great Britain, Germany,
Scandinavia, France, Australasia, Japan, China, and India. Dr. Mott showed
that the wonderful growth in all these lands during the last few years attests, beyond doubt, that the thinking mass of our universities are acknowledging Jesus
Christ as Lord and Savior.

4 4(rOHEN is all the hazing to be over? When may I wear college colors
without let or hindrance?'' To this recent query of a Freshman
the bystanders had no very definite answer to give. He was told to
''try it and see." So it has seemed advisable to say here, for the benefit of
those who do not know, that the discipline exerted by the Junior Class in such
minor matters stops, according to tradition, after the interclass football game.
"But there was hazing in the last college year at the end of February," some
one says. Very true, but it was for a special case. A group of '04 men attempted to interfere with the '03 banquet, and to prevent the attendance of
President Plaggetneyer. This was resented by the then Juniors, not only because they had declared nn their own part a policy of non-interference with
class banquets, but also because the matter occurred on the eve of the quarter
centennial celebration of the University, and the spectacle of undergraduates
engaged in a scuffle on the street would have been a sorry happening at a time
when the University was the center of attention. For these reasons, '03 enforced the regulations concerning college colors and class numerals for a couple
of weeks. The whole business, of course, is each year at the discretion of the
Junior Class. But there should be cogent and specific reasons for departing
from the tradition that peace and friendship reign after the class football game.

THE NEWS—LETTER,

7

HE mix up concerning this year's cane-rush is not very creditable to those
most actively concerned. Out of so many conflicting explanations for the
non-occurrence of the event, it is difficult to draw .a single theory. The
facts in the case are that the rush has not come off, that it may not come off
until after the holidays, and that it is poor class policy to let such an institution lapse. Previous classes have entered into the spirit of the rush, have carried it out successfully, and have benefitted by the opportunity to "let off
steam." If there is really a prevailing sentiment that the nature of the rush
includes au unnecessary amount of brutality, there could be substituted for it
cane "sprees," such as have been used at Princeton and other colleges. Three
champions are chosen from each class—light, middle, and heavy weight—and
the three pairs are matched to wrestle for the cane, which the two contestants
hold as do the class presidents in our plan. At any rate, the '04 and '05 men
are expected to do something besides accuse each other of backing out. Such
conduct belongs more to professional pugilism than to class athletics at an

t

American University.
THE MUSICAL CLUBS.

C

HE Clubs are now looking eagerly forward to the Christmas excursion,

now that the Hannah More trip, the last of the four trial concerts, is
over. From a musical point of view, this was only moderately successful. The Banjo Club i managed to get through its new piece, "Our Director,"
without comment froni the audience. The Mandolin Club did not keep up the
good start it had made; some portions of the "Loin du Pays" were extremely
ragged. A two-hour rehearsal on Saturday, however, did it much good. The
Glee Club is beginning to show the result of much hard work. Altogether,
prospects are good for creditable performances on the holiday trip.
This will extend from Monday, the 29th, to Friday, January 2. Details
are not quite settled, as it was only recently that the management found it necessary to abandon the first plan of an appearance at Norfolk. But, so far as
has been arranged, the dates will be as followE:
Monday, December 29—Leave on night boat of Baltimore, Chesapeake
and Atlantic Company.
Tuesday—Concert. and dance at Cambridge.
Wednesday—A real old "Easte'n Sho'" dinner—terrapin, ducks, etc.—at
Salisbury, followed by concert and dance at night.
Thursday—Concert and dance at Easton.
Friday—Return to Baltimore.
The men will be largely entertained at private houses, and prayers for snow
and narrow seated sleighs are being made by tho.e whose inclination leads them
to the society of the fair sex. However, a good time will be on hand in any
event for those who make the trip, and many are the anxious faces when three
or four of the management are seen with their heads together, deciding who
may best be spared in cutting down the number to be taken.

B. F. Cator,'04, has left the University.
A "feed" is to take place at the Hullabaloo Club on the night of Tuesday
the 23d, the last day of exams. Turkey and other holiday delicacies are
promised. It is understood that anyone mentioning the words "examination,"
paper," or "mark," will thereby render himself liable to immediate expulsion from the club rooms.

''

The '04 class flag, first displayed at the interclass football game, is the
handsomest seen at the University for sometime. It represents the class pill on
a background of college colors.
The failure to hold the cane-rush last week is differently explained by each
class concerned. The Juniors say that after the refusal of the Freshmen to
meet them on the day of the football game, they really have won by default, but
that they still are ready for '05 at any suitable time at American League Park.
The Freshmen assert that they held back on the 6th because told to by the
Seniors who had the affair in charge; that they have been ready to do battle
in the cage for ten days, but that the '04 men have refused under various pretexts, really bezause they have "cold feet." The only certain point seems to
be that there will be nothing done until after the holidays.
It is understood that the Goonay Club, an organization hitherto restricted
in membership to the Musical Clubs, has extended its scope, and now includes
members from the upper classes at large. The existence of some senior society,
the honor of membership in which the newly-entered undergraduate may look
forward to as at once an incentive and a reward for faithful services to his
Alma Mater, and for good behavior in his college relations, seems a most desirable thing. Attention was called to this in an article by Arthur W. Machen,
Jr., in THH NEWS-Lin-11m of December 6,1899, in which he says:
"The fraternities generally select their members during the first few weeks
of the freshman year; and thus almost the only positions which may be bestowed
as 'a reward of popularity are the class offices. Therefore, the only popularity
which an ambitious student need cultivate is popularity among his own classmates, and this is rather helped than hindered by a certain amount of freshness
towards his academic superiors. The only remedy for this state of affairs would
be the establishment of one or more junior or senior societies, to which the freshmen might look as the goal of their ambitions."
Some tangible evidence of the reality of this body might have been gleaned
by the uninitiated from sundry peculiar actions of grave and reverend seniors,
not otherwise easily explicable, during the recent weeks.

Herbarium, and secretary of the Wild Flower Reservation Society of
America, will deliver a lecture on ''The Vanishing Wild Flowers" in
Hopkins Hall, Friday, December 19 The lecture will be delivered under the
direction of the Naturalists Field Club.

conference of the Association of American Universities, which will meet in New
York, December 29, 30 and 31.
On Thursday, December 11, Dr. Remsen went to Washington to address
the Cosmos Club on Liebig and Wochler, the great German pioneers of Chenistry, with whom Dr. Remsen studied.
Dr. A. M. Elliott, Dr. J. H. Hollander, and Dr. Henry M. Hurd were
Present at the twenty-second annual meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League. Ex-president Gilman addressed the meeting on Thursday, the
11th of December, afterwards being elected President of the League.
At the B. C. C. Alumni Banquet on the 9th of this month, Dr. Jacob H.
Hollander responded to the toast,"The Political Economist and Public Affairs."
Early in March a course of lectures on Social Economics will be delivered
in French by Professor Leopold Mabilleau, director of the Musee Social. The
money for these lectures was given to the University by Dr. Elgin R. L. Gould,
City Chamberlaili of New York, who delivered a speech at the commencement
last June.
On December 5th, Mr. Theodore Marburg addressed the Johns Hopkins
Historical and Political Science Association on "The Eight-Hour Labor Law."
Professor Julius Haber, of the University of Karlsruhe, Germany, recently
visited the University. Professor Haber, who is the representative of the German Bunsen Society for Applied Physical Chemistry, was particularly interested
in Professor Morse's new apparatus for the measurement of osmatic pressure.
Dr. Jeffrey R. Brackett's course on Public Charity for th Economics Department begins on Thursday, the 18th. The course will consist of ten
conferences, held on the 18th, and the nine succeeding Tuesdays.
The University was visited last week by Professor Arthur Gamgee, the
great English physiological chemist. He was shown through the University
by Dr. Remsen.

THE NEWS-LETTER
THE FOOTBALL TEAM OF 1902.

NE is tempted, now that the period of storm and stress is over, to look
back upon the football season this year and make the comment "Same
old story." But it has not been the same old story by any means, and
therefore it is hardly just, to the college, or to the team, that the efforts made
and the success achieved should be passed over without a word of praise. To
a certain degree, the story of this year's struggle to place a satisfactory team on
the field is like that of former years; but never before have circumstances corn
limed so strongly against us, and accordingly the tenacity and pluck that
finally beat out a victory are more pronounced this season than in preceding
years.
The facts of the case are known to every undergraduate and every alumnus
who retains an active interest in University affairs, but a brief repetition of the
conditions that stood out so appallingly at the beginning of the fall term may
remind Hopkins men of what they have really accomplished. Of lest year's
eleven, two only remained in the college department of the University; one of
these men, Yearley, was extremely uncertain as to whether he would be able to
get into the game again this year. The other, Captain Blanck, in addition to
the worry and responsibility of making a team from almost nothing, was him
self handicapped by a badly torn ligament in his hip, the result of last year's
work. The incoming class was very light, the Junior class also had no very
large men; there was no one to replace the players who had graduted in 1902.
To make matters worse, the University was later in opening than usual, the
grounds that we expected to play on were mixed up in litigation, and there was
great uncertainty as to our securing them. Finally the few men who did turn
out for practice were many of them entirely unacquainted with the elements of
the game. It is no wonder that everyone, from the captain down, was not oversanguine as to results.
However, by dint of constant urging from Captain Blanck, and unceasing
effort on the part of all who were interested in having a team, a start was at
length made. There is no use going into the details; the meds came out, one
by one, until we had a backfield, men in the undergraduate school developed,
and some who had never thought of playing football came out at our time of
need. The scrub became more and more of a reality, regular practice produced
visible results, and finally Hopkins had a team—not what the wildest enthusiast could call a star team, but one that we all felt would do us credit when
it went on the field—a team that we feared would have to prove its mettle by
taking defeat like the sportsmen that we know they were.
It was with such a team, that had not played together in its entirety for a
whole week, that we met Western Maryland College for our first game. There
was one thing that manifested itself before we left Union Station and that
helped largely in the practical victory that we won later in the day. The whole
college understood the situation, knew the chances were slim, did not expect a
particularly good game, and yet they turned out en masse to accompany the

team on an all-day trip, just to show that
they were backing the Black and Blue any
how, under any circumstances, because it

when eleven men work together in that spirit

everything that enters into the question of a

was followed up by a decisive victory over

The finest part of the game was when Hopkins held them for six successive downs
CA1"fAIN 13L,ANCK.
within our last three yards of territory. That

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

alone was an exhibition worth all the work, and worry, and heart-burn that
the up hill fight for the whole season had cost.
And right here let me say that the purpose of this sketch was not to give
information that you all know, but to show as clearly as possible the credit
earned by our season, and to draw from it a lesson that will help us in the
future. As to the credit, it belongs in the'first place to Fred. C. Blanck. All
the work, and worry, and heart burn before mentioned fell first upon him, and
the sufferings of others were merely reflected and sympathetic in nature. The
task laid upon the captain this year was one that no man would like or willingly seek, and he fulfilled it right well. There is no need to amplify his
praise; every man who knows football at the University recognizes his deserts.
After the captain every man, 'Varsity or scrub, Med. or undergrad., who
slaved day after day in the cage for the honors of his college is entitled to and
receives the admiration and gratitude of everyone. Finally, the manager, the
coach, the trainer, and all who had the welfare of the team at heart, may feel
that they have aided a plucky and successful fight against circumstances.
Now for the moral. After this year, let us never say: "We cannot have
a team." It is never too late, and times are never too hard, to make a try, and
when we make a good, hard, try, that in itself is victory. This year we won
only a single game, tied one, and lost one; yet, beyond peradventure, everyone
is glad we did that instead of letting go, and having no team. Things can
never be worse than they have been; if they are we will just have to crowd on a
little more effort and win out anyhow. That is the spirit that Western Maryland never can permanently beat, the good old "Hopkins spirit."
H. B. S., '02.

THE JUNIOR-FRESHMAN FOOTBALL GAME.
HE gridiron at American League Park was covered with hard snow and
ice on Saturday, the sixth, when the Junior and Freshman elevens slid
into the field of vision. Upon each man's face was the determination to
hurdle icebergs if necessary, and to win in any event. This appeared in the
hard-fought game that followed, a game in which line-bucking was the feature,
since the backs had neglected to bring their skates, and end runs were impossible. In these straight plunges, the Juniors were just a little the better, and
with eighteen seconds to play in the second half, they scored a touchdown and
goal
The Juniors kicked off to Hudgins, who advanced the ball to the 40-yard
line. The slippery condition of the field made it impossible for the Freshmen
to try end runs, and consequently they pushed their backs through the line.
Stone, Chism and Wroth tore through the Junior line repeatedly. The hurdling of Stone for the Freshmen was excellent, and most of their gains came
in this way. The ball was pushed steadily down toward the Junior's goal
until it was on their 10-yard line.

e

13

1904 TRAM AND suBsTrruTD:s.
Here '04 braced up, and the Freshmen backs were unable to gain
through the line, and were forced to try for a goal from the field. The ball
was passed to Hudgins, but his kick went wide of the goal posts.
The Juniors kicked, and it was the Freshmen's ball again. They tried the
same tactics over, and again steadily advanced the ball to the Juniors 15-yard
line. Here they were held for downs, and, thereafter, '04's goal was not in the
least danger. The rest of the game was spent in punting by both teams, the
half ending with the ball in the possession of the Freshmen in the gjniddle of
the field.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

In the second half, the weight and experience of the Juniors began to
tell. The ball was in their possession almost the entire half. The Freshmen
played gamely, but they were unable to stop the fierce rushes of their opponents, who were straining every nerve for a touchdown. Tackle plays were
used again and again, with Pearre and Rosenfeld carrying the ball, and the
latter was finally pushed over the line with only eighteen more seconds to
play. Emig kicked goal, and the score stood 6 to 0 in favor of the Juniors.
In the short time remaining, nothing was done, the game ending with the
ball in mid-field.
The game was clean and well-played, notwithstanding the difficulty of
running on the slippery surface. The ice was responsible for several bad
kicks, it being impossible to get a sure foothold for the kick.
The announcement that the cane-rush was off disappointed the spectators,
especially the fair but blood-thirsty admirers. The Seniors, however, had received notice from the faculty that they would be held responsible for any accident, and President Tootle accordingly had the rush postponed.
It was a case of "root or freeze," and even the feminine spectators
joined with the classes in cheering their favorites. The Juniors occupied the
grand-stand, and their cheering was in charge of Crozier. The Freshmen
gathered themselves together in the bleachers, and kept themselves warm
with their yells. Each class tried to "out-root" the other,. but the honors
were about even. The Freshmen were led by Kinnane. At the close of the
game the classes ended the season of rivalry by cheering each other.
For the Juniors, Pearre, Strohbar, Emig and Rosenfeld played the best
game, while the Freshman stars were Stone, Chism and Wroth. The ends
had very little work to do, most of it falling on the backs of the two teams.

TRACK AND FIELD PROCEEDINGS.

(4)

RP.:PARATIONS are now being made by Physical Director Mackdermott
for three large indoor meets to be held in the cage sometime during the
first part of the year. These events will mark the most active winter in
the athletic history of Hopkins.
"Mack" is planning to bring off in May the biggest athletic event of the
year. He is working hard to arrange an inter-collegiate outdoor meet, in which
track and .field teams from the universities of Pennsylvania, Georgetown, Lehigh, and from several other institutions will compete. It is also intended to
invite teams from amateur organizations throughout Maryland and the District
of Columbia.
The first of the indoor meets will be an inter-class affair, and will be held
in the cage during the latter part of January. Mr. Mackdermott, Captain R.
C. Hoffman and Manager Dulany, of the track team, have the arrangements in
charge. There will be the usual track and field events, and an inter-class relay
race, for which a cup will be offered. Suitable prizes will also be given to the
winners of the other events. This meet will be followed by two other open
meets to he held in the cage sometime during February and March.
The relay team this year promises to be one of the best that ever represented the University. So far, there seems to be rather a dearth of weightthrowers, pole-vaulters, and hurdlers, but there will probably be some candidates out for these places after the holidays.

THE FABLE'01," THE LADY PRINCIPAL AND THE STRIKERS.

HIS is a fable which does not begin "once upon a time."
It was a critical moment. On the other side of the green baize curtain
could be heard the expectant hum of a hundred eager voices, for the
young ladies of the Annie Moore Seminary were assembled to hear the concert
given by the musical clubs of the Oysterville College. On the stage there was
no confusion, yet everything was indicative of the greatest excitement. There
stood the lady principal, faultlessly arrayed in a black silk with a white jabot at
the throat. There stood the manager of the clubs with a look of anguish bespread upon his Gibsonesque features. Three men, one from each club, corn
pleted the group. Beyond, in stolid silence, could be seen imperturable rows
of musical men, standing at parade rest. The situation was strained almost to
the breaking point. The musical clubs were on a strike.
"Please repeat your demands!" said the lady principal.

16

THE NEWS—LETTER.

"They are as follows," said the tall man with the deep voice and the
suave manner, "we are tired of giving concerts at girls' schools and immediately after the performance having to undergo the anguish of seeing the young
ladies trundled off to bed, inside of ten minutes. We are tired of being the
center of a system of espionage conducted by lynx eyed teachers, compared to
which the system of Sherlock Gillette is a three-spot in a dirty deck."
"Now that you have stated your objections, what are your demands?"
The committee looked at their comrades in the backgronnd and took courage. Again the deep, dulcet tones of the glee club's representative burdened
the air.
"We demand that the young ladies be permitted to remain up until eleven
o'clock." The lady principal turned pale. "We demand that you call off the
dogs of war; in plain English, all those females whose duty it is to be Johnnie
on-the-Spot." The lady principal fell limply into a chair. "We demand that
a certain number of cozy corners, one for each man, be provided with soft
cushions and dim lights." The lady principal went into a trance and with
difficulty was restored by the prompt application of smelling salts. At last she
opened her eyes.
"Is there anything else?" she asked with feeble irony.
"Nothing."
"And what if I refuse?"
"There'll be no concert tonight,'' the three responded in concert.
It was a moment of supreme portent, Seldom in the life of an individual
does it happen that such momentous questions are to be decided. Like a
drowning man grasping at a straw she turned to the genial manager. With
supreme resolve she smiled upon him, but guile was in her heart, and she said,''I
know that you can manage them. You are a natural leader."
"I am not the leader, I am the manager."
"But they will do what you say"

"Nothing doing," was the solemn reply.
"You have heard the ultimatum, madam, do you accede?"

THE BLACK SATCHEL.
CCJ M MODATION for Cleveland, Chicago, and the Northwest!"
bawled the porter, walking through the main waiting-room of the
depot. The few travelers who sat drowsily around roused themselves, and passed out of the warm station and through the grated doors into
the snow and cold of a winter night. I had just time to purchase my ticket,
and tightly clutching my small black satchel to step on the platform, when the
midnight train, its dazzling head-light cutting through the darkness, rolled into
the depot—ten minutes late.
Crossing several tracks, I walked quickly down the long line of baggage,
express, and passenger cars, and boarded the last coach. The steam rushed
and hissed angrily from the dome of the engine as if the mighty creature were
impatient at the delay, and wished to be off and once more rush through the
darkening clouds of snow, and awaken the sleeping hills and hollows with its
hoarse shriek. The huge engine quivered and shook, snorted once, twice, and
then again and again, moved slowly forward, and in a moment was well under
way, and tearing through the night with a thousand miles of track before it.
I settled myself back in my seat, and prepared to pass the long night ride
as comfortably as I could. The smell of smoke reached me, the door was
slammed, and the brakeman, carrying a lantern in each hand, passed through
the car, leaving me its sole occupant. Solitude, it is said, is most conducive
to thought, and in a short time the events of the day were passing through my
mind in rapid review, and in particular, those which had culminated in my
leaving New York at midnight for the West. I glanced at the small black
satchel which lay on the seat beside me, and instinctively felt for my arms.
My thought flew back to the first day, not many years ago—for I was still a
young man—that I had entered the service of Thomson & Blank, bankers, one
of the largest firms in Wall Street. By degrees I had worked my way up,
gradually gaining the esteem and good-will of the firm, till now I occupied the
chief place in their large establishment. Frequently before I had been sent on
errands similar to the one in which I was at present engaged, but none was
ever of such vast importance. Frequently large sums of money had been entrusted to my care, but never before such an amount as the small black satchel
now contained. It was in the afternoon of the first day of February, 1871, that
I had been called into the small private office of Mr. Thomson. It was an
hour later that I emerged, having received full instructions regarding my mission,—the details of which for certain reasons I will not make known,—but let
it suffice that I was to act as the firm's confidential agent in consummating one
of the largest deals in which it had ever been engaged.. The entire affair so far
44

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

as known to the firm and myself, had been kept a jealously guarded secret; but
to make certain that they could not be forestalled in the transaction, and for the
quicker transfer of such a sum, it was decided that I should leave that very
night.
With a start I came out of my reverie. I had almost dozed off. A little
frightened, and now throughly awake, I lit a cigar, and turning to the window
tried to gaze into the blackness beyond. We dashed through some small town,
scarcely distinguishable in the darkness and the storm, and in a moment left it
behind us. Straining my eyes in the effort to pierce the night, I saw the red
sparks streaming by, and occasionally caught the dim outline of a house or
tree We passed through a cut, the light from the car racing and dancing over
its snow-covered side, and framing in pale streaks the bushes and shrubbery that
raced by. Once more we emerged upon the open plain, rolling away to the
westward and lost in the black blur of the distant foothills. The train rumbled
over a trestle, the narrow rapid stream flowing far below. A chill passed over
me when I thought of the possibility of jumping the rail. I turned back to
the brightly lighted car, and gave a slight start. So absorbed had I been in
trying to pierce the darkness, that I had not heard two men enter, who now
occupied seats in front of me and on opposite Sides of the aisle. Evidently,
they were strangers, and each seemed absorbed with his own thoughts. I fell
to studying the man on my left; he was well built and of genteel appearance,
dressed quietly and with taste, his hair was jet black, and he was, at least as
far as I could judge from the profile turned toward me, of a dark complexion.
The second traveler was of the ordinary type, large, robust, and light-haired.
My cigar had gone out; I lit it again, and the dark man turned partly around
in his seat, then arose, and, approaching me with an easy grace, asked for a
match. I accommodated him, and he bowed slightly. "Going to Chicago?"
he said.
"Yes. Will you sit down?" And I made room for him on the seat beside
me. In a short time we were launched deeply in conversation. Time passed
and the train rushed on, the cars swinging and jarring as we rounded some
curve. My companion I soon found to be an educated and well-read man.
Presently, however, the conversation began to lag, and laying his cigar down
on the arm of his seat, the stranger seemed lost in thought. I glanced at the
other occupant of the coach. He was to all appearances asleep.
Somehow I was seized by a terrible presentiment of impending danger, one
of those inexplicable sensations which sometimes come to a man in battle or in
times of great excitement. I turned to my companion, and uttered a cry. He
had risen from his seat, and standing in the aisle, with an indescrible look upon
his dark face, was pointing toward the rear of the car. He wheeled about like
a flash. There was a crashing blow on my head, lights innumerable danced
before my eyes, my brain was on fire. I seemed to be sinking, sinking, for
countless ages always down, down, and at last was smothered and swallowed
up in darkness, and then drowsiness came over me. I had no desire to see or to
hear, only a great longing to forget. It seemed as if the current of my mind
had stopped.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
On opening my eyes I became conscious of a burning pain in my head.
My first thought was of the black satchel. I felt beside me. It was gone!
I was bewildered, semi conscious, and possessed by an awful feeling of
unreality. My surroundings were not familiar, but by degrees as my mind
gradually cleared, I became aware that I was lying on a hard, polished floor
beside a couch. I put my hand to my head; it was covered with blood. There
was blood also upon the floor. I must have had a severe fall.
The room was spacious and magnificently furnished. Strange! I did not
know where I was. Then I thought of the satchel and my mission and grew
sick at the thought. I heard a light foot step, and a lady entered the room.
She was of middle age and still handsome.
"We dine at six, John," she said softly.
Turning to her I replied bluntly, "Where am I?"
"J—J—Why, really, what is the matter," stammered the lady. "Are you
feeling—er—as well as usual, John?"
"In heaven's name—," I began, "where am I, and who are you?"
"I am your wife and you are in your own home in London. Don't you
know—"
"How do I know?" I cried wildly. ti 9,
"You have gone mad,'' she said.
Turning I saw a large mirror at one end of the room. I quickly approached
it, but fell back aghast. In place of my own,features the mirror reflected theface
of an old man—a man prematurely aged,—with white locks and a long snowy beard!
I looked at myself with horror-stricken eyes and jaw half fallen. Then every
object danced around me, the room and the lady became lost in a giddy maze,
and my senses failed
When I regained consciousness, I found myself in bed, with kind though
unfamiliar faces around me. A violent fever kept me for weeks within the
shadow -of death, but thanks to the tender care of the lady who had claimed to
be my wife, I slowly recovered. During my convalescence I was told the story
of my second life. It was for the most part ordinary enough. I had turned
up in London one day, a poor but perfectly rational man, but without the
slightest remembrances of my life previous to the night adventure in the railway car. I had engaged in business, met with success, and married, and
would have died without ever having found out my real name, had not my fall
from a sofa upon the hard floor and the consequent injury to my head restored
my reason in a manner most miraculous. All this and much besides my wife
told me as I recovered slowly from my long illness.
The story of my early life was nearly as much of a relevation to my wife as
her story was to me. I was now once more a healthy and happy man. And
there remains but little more to tell. My first duty was to communicate with
my old employers, Thomson & Blank. The result of my inquiry was to find
out that the partnership had been long since dissolved and that both the old
gentlemen were dead. They, as I myself, would never learn the fate of the
black satchel.
E. P. SANPRocK, '03.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
THE LOOM OF DREAMS.
What shall I weave upon my loom of dreams
To give my lady in a dainty rhyme?
Some sylvan memory of summer time,
Of silent woods and slow and sleepy streams?
Some fantasy of fairy-like design,
With opal woof and warp of amethyst,
Like little waves by melting moon-beams kissed
When it cloth seem the stars forget to shine?
Or shall it be a song in martial strain,
Or a wild song of the wild, winter sea?
A dirge for A atunin, a low threnody,
As if the wind did to the moon complain?
No, none of these; for her my dream-loom weaves
Dream-fancies of a land forever Spring;
Where fountains 'neath the wooing willows sing
Of youth and love, echoed by rustling leaves.
Such was the scene those Springs in Arcady
When still the gods inhabited the vales,
And l'an went piping through the grassy dales
With dancing nymphs to keep him company.
Just such a fancy shall my dream-loom weave,
All built of airy nothings which are gone
On waking, like the yellow stars at dawn;
And yet the mind some impress doth receive,
Some impress faint, as of a long-lost song
Heard once in childhood from a crooning nurse.
I'll charm my lady's ear with such a verse
As might be sung at eve by elfin throng.
'Tis this I'll weave out of the idle air
To cast around her in a mystic spell;
0 may she own she could not think to dwell
E'en in that dream unles4 I could be there!

4 4(rOHEN is all the hazing to be over? When may I wear college colors
without let or hindrance?'' To this recent query of a Freshman
the bystanders had no very definite answer to give. He was told to
''try it and see." So it has seemed advisable to say here, for the benefit of
those who do not know, that the discipline exerted by the Junior Class in such
minor matters stops, according to tradition, after the interclass football game.
"But there was hazing in the last college year at the end of February," some
one says. Very true, but it was for a special case. A group of '04 men attempted to interfere with the '03 banquet, and to prevent the attendance of
President Plaggetneyer. This was resented by the then Juniors, not only because they had declared nn their own part a policy of non-interference with
class banquets, but also because the matter occurred on the eve of the quarter
centennial celebration of the University, and the spectacle of undergraduates
engaged in a scuffle on the street would have been a sorry happening at a time
when the University was the center of attention. For these reasons, '03 enforced the regulations concerning college colors and class numerals for a couple
of weeks. The whole business, of course, is each year at the discretion of the
Junior Class. But there should be cogent and specific reasons for departing
from the tradition that peace and friendship reign after the class football game.

HE mix up concerning this year's cane-rush is not very creditable to those
most actively concerned. Out of so many conflicting explanations for the
non-occurrence of the event, it is difficult to draw .a single theory. The
facts in the case are that the rush has not come off, that it may not come off
until after the holidays, and that it is poor class policy to let such an institution lapse. Previous classes have entered into the spirit of the rush, have carried it out successfully, and have benefitted by the opportunity to "let off
steam." If there is really a prevailing sentiment that the nature of the rush
includes au unnecessary amount of brutality, there could be substituted for it
cane "sprees," such as have been used at Princeton and other colleges. Three
champions are chosen from each class—light, middle, and heavy weight—and
the three pairs are matched to wrestle for the cane, which the two contestants
hold as do the class presidents in our plan. At any rate, the '04 and '05 men
are expected to do something besides accuse each other of backing out. Such
conduct belongs more to professional pugilism than to class athletics at an

t

American University.
THE MUSICAL CLUBS.

C

HE Clubs are now looking eagerly forward to the Christmas excursion,

now that the Hannah More trip, the last of the four trial concerts, is
over. From a musical point of view, this was only moderately successful. The Banjo Club i managed to get through its new piece, "Our Director,"
without comment froni the audience. The Mandolin Club did not keep up the
good start it had made; some portions of the "Loin du Pays" were extremely
ragged. A two-hour rehearsal on Saturday, however, did it much good. The
Glee Club is beginning to show the result of much hard work. Altogether,
prospects are good for creditable performances on the holiday trip.
This will extend from Monday, the 29th, to Friday, January 2. Details
are not quite settled, as it was only recently that the management found it necessary to abandon the first plan of an appearance at Norfolk. But, so far as
has been arranged, the dates will be as followE:
Monday, December 29—Leave on night boat of Baltimore, Chesapeake
and Atlantic Company.
Tuesday—Concert. and dance at Cambridge.
Wednesday—A real old "Easte'n Sho'" dinner—terrapin, ducks, etc.—at
Salisbury, followed by concert and dance at night.
Thursday—Concert and dance at Easton.
Friday—Return to Baltimore.
The men will be largely entertained at private houses, and prayers for snow
and narrow seated sleighs are being made by tho.e whose inclination leads them
to the society of the fair sex. However, a good time will be on hand in any
event for those who make the trip, and many are the anxious faces when three
or four of the management are seen with their heads together, deciding who
may best be spared in cutting down the number to be taken.

The '04 class flag, first displayed at the interclass football game, is the
handsomest seen at the University for sometime. It represents the class pill on
a background of college colors.
The failure to hold the cane-rush last week is differently explained by each
class concerned. The Juniors say that after the refusal of the Freshmen to
meet them on the day of the football game, they really have won by default, but
that they still are ready for '05 at any suitable time at American League Park.
The Freshmen assert that they held back on the 6th because told to by the
Seniors who had the affair in charge; that they have been ready to do battle
in the cage for ten days, but that the '04 men have refused under various pretexts, really bezause they have "cold feet." The only certain point seems to
be that there will be nothing done until after the holidays.
It is understood that the Goonay Club, an organization hitherto restricted
in membership to the Musical Clubs, has extended its scope, and now includes
members from the upper classes at large. The existence of some senior society,
the honor of membership in which the newly-entered undergraduate may look
forward to as at once an incentive and a reward for faithful services to his
Alma Mater, and for good behavior in his college relations, seems a most desirable thing. Attention was called to this in an article by Arthur W. Machen,
Jr., in THH NEWS-Lin-11m of December 6,1899, in which he says:
"The fraternities generally select their members during the first few weeks
of the freshman year; and thus almost the only positions which may be bestowed
as 'a reward of popularity are the class offices. Therefore, the only popularity
which an ambitious student need cultivate is popularity among his own classmates, and this is rather helped than hindered by a certain amount of freshness
towards his academic superiors. The only remedy for this state of affairs would
be the establishment of one or more junior or senior societies, to which the freshmen might look as the goal of their ambitions."
Some tangible evidence of the reality of this body might have been gleaned
by the uninitiated from sundry peculiar actions of grave and reverend seniors,
not otherwise easily explicable, during the recent weeks.

THE NEWS-LETTER
THE FOOTBALL TEAM OF 1902.

NE is tempted, now that the period of storm and stress is over, to look
back upon the football season this year and make the comment "Same
old story." But it has not been the same old story by any means, and
therefore it is hardly just, to the college, or to the team, that the efforts made
and the success achieved should be passed over without a word of praise. To
a certain degree, the story of this year's struggle to place a satisfactory team on
the field is like that of former years; but never before have circumstances corn
limed so strongly against us, and accordingly the tenacity and pluck that
finally beat out a victory are more pronounced this season than in preceding
years.
The facts of the case are known to every undergraduate and every alumnus
who retains an active interest in University affairs, but a brief repetition of the
conditions that stood out so appallingly at the beginning of the fall term may
remind Hopkins men of what they have really accomplished. Of lest year's
eleven, two only remained in the college department of the University; one of
these men, Yearley, was extremely uncertain as to whether he would be able to
get into the game again this year. The other, Captain Blanck, in addition to
the worry and responsibility of making a team from almost nothing, was him
self handicapped by a badly torn ligament in his hip, the result of last year's
work. The incoming class was very light, the Junior class also had no very
large men; there was no one to replace the players who had graduted in 1902.
To make matters worse, the University was later in opening than usual, the
grounds that we expected to play on were mixed up in litigation, and there was
great uncertainty as to our securing them. Finally the few men who did turn
out for practice were many of them entirely unacquainted with the elements of
the game. It is no wonder that everyone, from the captain down, was not oversanguine as to results.
However, by dint of constant urging from Captain Blanck, and unceasing
effort on the part of all who were interested in having a team, a start was at
length made. There is no use going into the details; the meds came out, one
by one, until we had a backfield, men in the undergraduate school developed,
and some who had never thought of playing football came out at our time of
need. The scrub became more and more of a reality, regular practice produced
visible results, and finally Hopkins had a team—not what the wildest enthusiast could call a star team, but one that we all felt would do us credit when
it went on the field—a team that we feared would have to prove its mettle by
taking defeat like the sportsmen that we know they were.
It was with such a team, that had not played together in its entirety for a
whole week, that we met Western Maryland College for our first game. There
was one thing that manifested itself before we left Union Station and that
helped largely in the practical victory that we won later in the day. The whole
college understood the situation, knew the chances were slim, did not expect a
particularly good game, and yet they turned out en masse to accompany the

O

•

THE NEWS—LliTTER.

11

team on an all-day trip, just to show that
they were backing the Black and Blue any
how, under any circumstances, because it
was our team. While the two captains were
discussing the length of the halves atWestminster, a Western Maryland man said,
Oh, you fellows always say you are weak,
and then lick us. We can't beat Hopkins;
Your spirit won't let you lose." He was
honestly of the opinion that we were insuperable, regardless of apparent lack of strength.
It is unnecessary to go into the details of
the game. Every man on the team felt that
Whether he was a crack player or not, his
best was the only thing he could give, and
when eleven men work together in that spirit
they are not easy victims for anyone. When
everything that enters into the question of a
game is considered, weight, experience, organization, prestige, a record to sustain, an
old score to wipe out, home grounds, a sympathetic audience—the chances were all with
W. M. C.
In spite of
this, Hopkins was
COACH GARWOOD.
the winner until the last minute of play, and
even then Western Maryland was rendered
hysterical with joy at being able to tie the
score. Undoubtedly, 6 to 6 this year was as
decisive a success for J. H. U. as 12 to 0 was
last year.
The start made with Western Maryland
was followed up by a decisive victory over
M. A. C., which was, however, more of a
try-out for the Thanksgiving Day struggle,
than an ultimate object in itself. The chances
on paper for the U. of Md. contest were more
in our favor than the first game of the season,
yet the unexpected development of their
team, and the introduction of seven old football men in the last week, turned the tables.
As it was, the game our fellows put up was
a thing to be proud of. In the end, Maryland was barely able to score once, and in the
first half we gained through them at will.
The finest part of the game was when Hopkins held them for six successive downs
CA1"fAIN 13L,ANCK.
within our last three yards of territory. That

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

alone was an exhibition worth all the work, and worry, and heart-burn that
the up hill fight for the whole season had cost.
And right here let me say that the purpose of this sketch was not to give
information that you all know, but to show as clearly as possible the credit
earned by our season, and to draw from it a lesson that will help us in the
future. As to the credit, it belongs in the'first place to Fred. C. Blanck. All
the work, and worry, and heart burn before mentioned fell first upon him, and
the sufferings of others were merely reflected and sympathetic in nature. The
task laid upon the captain this year was one that no man would like or willingly seek, and he fulfilled it right well. There is no need to amplify his
praise; every man who knows football at the University recognizes his deserts.
After the captain every man, 'Varsity or scrub, Med. or undergrad., who
slaved day after day in the cage for the honors of his college is entitled to and
receives the admiration and gratitude of everyone. Finally, the manager, the
coach, the trainer, and all who had the welfare of the team at heart, may feel
that they have aided a plucky and successful fight against circumstances.
Now for the moral. After this year, let us never say: "We cannot have
a team." It is never too late, and times are never too hard, to make a try, and
when we make a good, hard, try, that in itself is victory. This year we won
only a single game, tied one, and lost one; yet, beyond peradventure, everyone
is glad we did that instead of letting go, and having no team. Things can
never be worse than they have been; if they are we will just have to crowd on a
little more effort and win out anyhow. That is the spirit that Western Maryland never can permanently beat, the good old "Hopkins spirit."
H. B. S., '02.

THE JUNIOR-FRESHMAN FOOTBALL GAME.
HE gridiron at American League Park was covered with hard snow and
ice on Saturday, the sixth, when the Junior and Freshman elevens slid
into the field of vision. Upon each man's face was the determination to
hurdle icebergs if necessary, and to win in any event. This appeared in the
hard-fought game that followed, a game in which line-bucking was the feature,
since the backs had neglected to bring their skates, and end runs were impossible. In these straight plunges, the Juniors were just a little the better, and
with eighteen seconds to play in the second half, they scored a touchdown and
goal
The Juniors kicked off to Hudgins, who advanced the ball to the 40-yard
line. The slippery condition of the field made it impossible for the Freshmen
to try end runs, and consequently they pushed their backs through the line.
Stone, Chism and Wroth tore through the Junior line repeatedly. The hurdling of Stone for the Freshmen was excellent, and most of their gains came
in this way. The ball was pushed steadily down toward the Junior's goal
until it was on their 10-yard line.

e

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

1904 TRAM AND suBsTrruTD:s.
Here '04 braced up, and the Freshmen backs were unable to gain
through the line, and were forced to try for a goal from the field. The ball
was passed to Hudgins, but his kick went wide of the goal posts.
The Juniors kicked, and it was the Freshmen's ball again. They tried the
same tactics over, and again steadily advanced the ball to the Juniors 15-yard
line. Here they were held for downs, and, thereafter, '04's goal was not in the
least danger. The rest of the game was spent in punting by both teams, the
half ending with the ball in the possession of the Freshmen in the gjniddle of
the field.

TRAM AND SUBSTITUTES.

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

In the second half, the weight and experience of the Juniors began to
tell. The ball was in their possession almost the entire half. The Freshmen
played gamely, but they were unable to stop the fierce rushes of their opponents, who were straining every nerve for a touchdown. Tackle plays were
used again and again, with Pearre and Rosenfeld carrying the ball, and the
latter was finally pushed over the line with only eighteen more seconds to
play. Emig kicked goal, and the score stood 6 to 0 in favor of the Juniors.
In the short time remaining, nothing was done, the game ending with the
ball in mid-field.
The game was clean and well-played, notwithstanding the difficulty of
running on the slippery surface. The ice was responsible for several bad
kicks, it being impossible to get a sure foothold for the kick.
The announcement that the cane-rush was off disappointed the spectators,
especially the fair but blood-thirsty admirers. The Seniors, however, had received notice from the faculty that they would be held responsible for any accident, and President Tootle accordingly had the rush postponed.
It was a case of "root or freeze," and even the feminine spectators
joined with the classes in cheering their favorites. The Juniors occupied the
grand-stand, and their cheering was in charge of Crozier. The Freshmen
gathered themselves together in the bleachers, and kept themselves warm
with their yells. Each class tried to "out-root" the other,. but the honors
were about even. The Freshmen were led by Kinnane. At the close of the
game the classes ended the season of rivalry by cheering each other.
For the Juniors, Pearre, Strohbar, Emig and Rosenfeld played the best
game, while the Freshman stars were Stone, Chism and Wroth. The ends
had very little work to do, most of it falling on the backs of the two teams.

TRACK AND FIELD PROCEEDINGS.

(4)

RP.:PARATIONS are now being made by Physical Director Mackdermott
for three large indoor meets to be held in the cage sometime during the
first part of the year. These events will mark the most active winter in
the athletic history of Hopkins.
"Mack" is planning to bring off in May the biggest athletic event of the
year. He is working hard to arrange an inter-collegiate outdoor meet, in which
track and .field teams from the universities of Pennsylvania, Georgetown, Lehigh, and from several other institutions will compete. It is also intended to
invite teams from amateur organizations throughout Maryland and the District
of Columbia.
The first of the indoor meets will be an inter-class affair, and will be held
in the cage during the latter part of January. Mr. Mackdermott, Captain R.
C. Hoffman and Manager Dulany, of the track team, have the arrangements in
charge. There will be the usual track and field events, and an inter-class relay
race, for which a cup will be offered. Suitable prizes will also be given to the
winners of the other events. This meet will be followed by two other open
meets to he held in the cage sometime during February and March.
The relay team this year promises to be one of the best that ever represented the University. So far, there seems to be rather a dearth of weightthrowers, pole-vaulters, and hurdlers, but there will probably be some candidates out for these places after the holidays.

THE FABLE'01," THE LADY PRINCIPAL AND THE STRIKERS.

HIS is a fable which does not begin "once upon a time."
It was a critical moment. On the other side of the green baize curtain
could be heard the expectant hum of a hundred eager voices, for the
young ladies of the Annie Moore Seminary were assembled to hear the concert
given by the musical clubs of the Oysterville College. On the stage there was
no confusion, yet everything was indicative of the greatest excitement. There
stood the lady principal, faultlessly arrayed in a black silk with a white jabot at
the throat. There stood the manager of the clubs with a look of anguish bespread upon his Gibsonesque features. Three men, one from each club, corn
pleted the group. Beyond, in stolid silence, could be seen imperturable rows
of musical men, standing at parade rest. The situation was strained almost to
the breaking point. The musical clubs were on a strike.
"Please repeat your demands!" said the lady principal.

16

THE NEWS—LETTER.

"They are as follows," said the tall man with the deep voice and the
suave manner, "we are tired of giving concerts at girls' schools and immediately after the performance having to undergo the anguish of seeing the young
ladies trundled off to bed, inside of ten minutes. We are tired of being the
center of a system of espionage conducted by lynx eyed teachers, compared to
which the system of Sherlock Gillette is a three-spot in a dirty deck."
"Now that you have stated your objections, what are your demands?"
The committee looked at their comrades in the backgronnd and took courage. Again the deep, dulcet tones of the glee club's representative burdened
the air.
"We demand that the young ladies be permitted to remain up until eleven
o'clock." The lady principal turned pale. "We demand that you call off the
dogs of war; in plain English, all those females whose duty it is to be Johnnie
on-the-Spot." The lady principal fell limply into a chair. "We demand that
a certain number of cozy corners, one for each man, be provided with soft
cushions and dim lights." The lady principal went into a trance and with
difficulty was restored by the prompt application of smelling salts. At last she
opened her eyes.
"Is there anything else?" she asked with feeble irony.
"Nothing."
"And what if I refuse?"
"There'll be no concert tonight,'' the three responded in concert.
It was a moment of supreme portent, Seldom in the life of an individual
does it happen that such momentous questions are to be decided. Like a
drowning man grasping at a straw she turned to the genial manager. With
supreme resolve she smiled upon him, but guile was in her heart, and she said,''I
know that you can manage them. You are a natural leader."
"I am not the leader, I am the manager."
"But they will do what you say"

"Fellows, is there anything doing?"
"Nothing doing," was the solemn reply.
"You have heard the ultimatum, madam, do you accede?"
